journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Robust control for a direct-driven permanent magnetic synchronous generator without mechanical sensors based on model reference adaptive backstepping control method

article-meta.aff: 2Key Laboratory of Measurement and Control of Complex Systems of Engineering of Ministry of Education, Southeast University, China

author-notes.corresp: Hui Zu, School of Automation, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China. Email: alex.hui.zu@gmail.com

abstract.p: This article is concerned with the robust control issues of direct-driven permanent magnetic synchronous generator without mechanical sensors. In this study, a novel nonlinear model reference adaptive backstepping control method is proposed. Extended electromotive force estimation-based rotor position and rotational velocity estimation methods are adopted, in which the stator parameters are identified online. Since the identified parameters are merely used in extended electromotive force estimator, the mathematically controlled plant cannot reflect the actual model, which decreases the robustness of the control. To provide a high-performance robust controller against uncertainties in stator parameters and mechanical torque fluctuation, a torque observer is adopted, and an adaptation law is derived with the identified parameters and estimated mechanical torque, in the sense of the Lyapunov theory. Meanwhile, the feasibility of the substitution of the actual stator parameters and state vector with estimated values is mathematically demonstrated based on the Lyapunov theory. Simulation experiments have been carried out both in surface permanent magnetic synchronous generator and interior permanent magnetic synchronous generator, and the results show that compared to the conventional process-interaction decoupling controller, the proposed controller has better disturbance rejection performance against wind speed perpetuation and parameter uncertainties.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The permanent magnetic synchronous generator (PMSG) directly driven by a wind turbine and connected to the grid by a full-power back-to-back converter has become an attractive alternative to the doubly fed induction generator (DFIG) because of the avoidance of the usage of a gearbox, the high efficiency and high power density of PMSG, and the network disturbances rejection capability of the front-end converter, and so on.1,2 A widely used strategy to control a PMSG is the field-oriented vector control approach,3 by which a practical structure of cascade control loops, including a loop of speed and two loops of current, is employed, and then the speed and current can be controlled separately. To implement speed closed-loop control, the rotor position and velocity information should be obtained, and the simplest approach is to install the rotor shaft mechanical sensors. However, large-scale wind power-generating systems are often located on top of the tower far from the floor, where using the mechanical sensors not only increases costs but, more importantly, reduces system reliability and greatly increases the difficulty and cost of the unit’s maintenance. In order to reduce the defect, the mechanical speed sensorless control technology, which obtains rotor position and velocity information with electric sensors indirectly, becomes the preferred scheme in the PMSG-equipped wind energy conversion system (WECS).

These mechanical speed sensorless control methods can be mainly divided into three classes: (a) those using open-loop method based on an ideal motor model,4–6 (b) those using nonideal characteristics of the motor,7–10 and (c) those using closed-loop algorithm based on a variety of observers.11–20 Methods such as the direct calculation method,4 inductances estimation method,5 and electromotive force (EMF) estimation method6 belong to the first class. These methods are suitable for rough estimation merely because of the strong dependence on the rotor parameters and the accumulation and nonelimination of estimation errors. The second class, which includes methods such as the high-frequency injection method,7,8 low-frequency injection method,9 and indirect flux detection by on-line reactance measurement (INFORM) method,10 is suitable for start- and low-speed region observation because the amplitude of high-frequency signals used for position estimation does not depend on rotating velocity.

The third class includes the model reference adaptive system (MRAS) method,14,15,17–20 sliding observer for flux estimation-based method,21 extended Kalman filter (EKF) method,11–13,16 and other such methods. Of these methods, position information is extracted from the EMF directly or indirectly, and the feedback effect greatly improves the accuracy, the observation robustness, and the system stability. Since the amplitude of the back EMF is proportional to the electrical angular velocity, the signal-to-noise ratio of the back EMF is low at standstill and in the low-speed region, and combined with other confounding factors, the estimation of these methods are not accurate in these regions. Fortunately, the large-scale direct-driven PMSG (DD-PMSG) has a lot of pole pairs, so even with the wind turbine in the low-velocity region, the electrical angular velocity would not be too low. Additionally, the start-up of large scale WECS is directly driven by wind until the generation system can be parallel in, and none of the speed and position estimation is needed at these regions. Consequently, the low signal-to-noise ratio defect of the above methods at these regions is ignored while the advantage is pay attention for the application in large scale PMSG-equipped direct-driven WECS (DD-WECS).

Among the closed-loop observer-based angular position and velocity estimation method, the MRAS-based extended EMF (EEMF) estimation method has been widely used because of its noniterative and robustness features. To improve EEMF estimation accuracy, the online identification technology for stator parameters is introduced.14,15,17–20 On the other hand, due to the randomness of the wind speed, the aerodynamic torque is also uncertain. To make the rotor velocity keep up with the rapid changes in wind speed, aerodynamic torque should also be provided.

Unfortunately, the aerodynamic torque is very tough to measure, and hence the torque estimation technology is scarcely applied. In addition, the online-identified results have rarely been used by controllers under the traditional decoupling current control frame14,15,18,20 based on the field-orientation mechanism,3 for which the process interaction (PI) control is still extensively used. As is known, because of the limited stability margin, the robustness of the linear PI controller is poor against nonlinear parameter uncertainties and torque disturbances.

Considering mechanical torque disturbance and parameter variations rejection techniques, there are two main classes of control methods. The first class concentrates on the control mechanism to provide robustness. In Mouni et al.22 and Hsien et al.,23
H
∞
loop shaping design procedure is applied to design speed controller of a permanent magnetic synchronous motor (PMSM). By transforming the PMSM model to a linear system plus limited upper-bound uncertainties, these methods provide robustness to a certain extent with the cost of conservative aroused by the linearization and limitation upper-bound dealings. To solve the problem, a series of cost-guaranteed methods24 or nonlinear
H
∞
control schemes25,26 are proposed. However, the complex performance indexes and complex online computation existed in these algorithms bring too much complex computations to be engineering implementation. Although sliding mode control schemes26,27 can provide enough robustness against parameters and torque disturbances they greatly degrade the service life of the mechanical system due to the resulting switching jitters. Owing to the disadvantages, these schemes are not widely applied in PMSG/PMSM drives.

The second class is based on disturbance compensation techniques to provide a signal to offset the model and external disturbances. Robust proportional–integral–derivative (PID) control,28 adaptive disturbance rejection control,29 model reference adaptive control,30 and other such controls belong to this class. Depending on a disturbance observer (DO), these methods estimate the model errors and compensate them at the output of a controller as a part of the control signal. Taking into account the DD-PMSG mechanical speed sensorless control system, the model error is mainly introduced by (a) parameter variations and model error between the mathematical model and actual model; (b) estimation error introduced in the feedback channel from the estimated position and velocity signal; (c) inaccurate measurement of wind speed; and (d) the wind speed variations, that is, the mechanical torque disturbance between measurement gaps; any model error introduced in these loops is strongly nonlinear, so conventional linear PI controller, as well as linear
H
∞
controller, must not meet the high-performance control requirements. On the contrary, the disturbance compensation-based control scheme attempts to estimate the total disturbance concern nothing for the trends of disturbance causing the model changes in each specific. Additionally, the concept of disturbance compensation is closely associated with the understanding of application; thus, it is easy to be implemented and applied in engineering.28,29,31,32

In this article, a model reference adaptive backstepping control (MRABC) method-based robust velocity controller is proposed, of which the parameters are closed-loop adjusted by the online identified stator parameters, estimated position, and velocity information. The using of the identified results by controller adaptive mechanism makes the DO only estimates error terms, introduced by inaccuracy estimation of parameters and aerodynamic moment. These error terms vary around zero in normal operation so it is easy to estimate. Compared to the conventional PI-decoupling control, the proposed method obviously eases the estimated pressure from complex perturbation, and therefore, the precision and robustness of the control have been significantly increased. This article also theoretically demonstrates the feasibility of the replacement of actual parameters of PMSG with estimated ones during EEMF estimation.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In ‘Mathematical model’, modeling of the DD-PMSG is presented. In ‘EEMF estimation and stability analysis’, the stability of the estimation is theoretically demonstrated. In ‘Proposed robust control scheme’, the robust velocity controller is proposed. Evaluation results are provided in ‘Simulation results’. Finally conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: Controlled plant specification
sec.p: Under the decoupling vector control frame, the given rotor velocity and zero given current of d-axis are the two inputs of the controlling system; correspondingly, the rotor velocity and d-axis current are the outputs of the system. Assuming a reference model is introduced with the same input and output, the controller is required to make the errors between the input and output as small as possible as the wind speed and stator parameters vary. On the other hand, if the estimated parameters can be effectively used in the controller of PMSG, the estimation pressure of adaptive mechanism will be greatly reduced. Additionally, because of the inaccuracy in parameters identification and position and velocity estimation, the adaptive controller is also required to achieve adequate robustness against the inaccuracy parameters and state variables.
To achieve the robust controller, several points about the DD-PMSG model should be explained.

list-item.p:
Remark 1. Due to the inaccuracy estimation of rotor position, the
d – q
rotating coordination reference frame drifts off to the
γ – δ
estimated rotational frame. Similar to the case in
d – q
frame, the γ-axis and δ-axis currents can be decoupled as
i
γ
*
= 0
is set. Therefore, the conventional decoupling vector control structure3 can be adopted.

Remark 2. In the case of the WECS start-up, flux-weakening control, a sudden short circuit, and so on, the significant demagnetization current appears in the PMSG, which generates demagnetizing field and dramatically decreases the permanent magnetic operating point. However, in the case of a well-designed neodymium-iron-boron (NdFeB) PMSG, the permanent magnetic (PM) operating point is above the inflection point of demagnetization curve in maximum operating temperature, which can avoid the total or partial field losses. Therefore, PM flux
ϕ
is assumed to be constant in the following contents.

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p: The proposed method is investigated by means of simulations. The MATLAB/Simulink environment is used for the simulations with reference to a 2-MW DD-PMSG. The configuration of proposed control scheme is shown in Figure 3, and the machine data are given in Table 1.

caption.p: Controlling schematic.
PMSG: permanent magnetic synchronous generator; EEMF: extended electromotive force; MPPT: maximum power point tracking.
Specification of the DD-PMSG

fn.p: DD-PMSG: direct-driven permanent magnetic synchronous generator.

sec.p:
The proposed control system is set up as follows. First, the directly detected three-phase current signals are transformed to the
α – β
stationary reference frame. Then, by using the Park transformation, these signals are transformed to the
γ – δ
frame with the estimated position. Next, with the
γ – δ
frame signals,
R
s
,
L
d
, and
L
q
are identified with the least square method mentioned in Ickikawa et al.,14 and a low-pass filter, of which the decay time constants are set to 10 s for resistance parameter and 0.5 s for inductance parameters, respectively, is applied to remove high-frequency interference. Finally, these identified results have been supplied to EEMF observer and then the estimated EEMF signal is obtained to estimate the rotor position and velocity, which, in turn, are fed to the controller and the Park transformer for the feedback control. The parameters of proposed controller are tuned as follows:
k
m 1
= 200
,
k
m 2
= 50
,
k
m 3
= 20
,
k
1
= 5
,

= 100
,
k
3
= 1000
,
λ
1
= 500
,
λ
2
= 10
, and
λ
3
= 0 . 0001
. To check the maximum wind energy extracting performance, the following wind turbine model proposed in Slootweg et al.35 is introduced.

where

Considering that the identified results and estimated mechanical torque are not used in most mechanical speed sensorless controllers, the comparison studies have been carried out among the proposed algorithm and the conventional PI decoupling controller.14 The parameters of each controller are tuned as follows:

I
= 7 . 2
for current controllers. To verify the feasibility of the proposed controller, different operating conditions have been considered. Some selected results are presented as follows.

sec.title: Dynamic and steady-state performance
sec.p:
The comparison is carried out with the PMSG parameters constant, while the wind speed increases from 8 to 10 m/s at 4 s. The actual rotor velocity and estimated values are presented in Figure 4. As can be seen, the responses of the two strategies are almost the same, which shows that as the parameters are nominal, the controlled plant model does not change, thus the estimated model errors
δ
^
1
,
δ
^
2
, and
δ
^
3
, which are estimated by the DO of adaptive controller, are close to 0.

caption.p: The comparison of dynamic and steady-state performance with nominal stator parameters.
PI: proportional–integral control

sec.title: Robustness to mechanical torque disturbance
sec.p:
Assuming that the wind speed increases from 8 to 10 m/s at 5 s and decreases back to 8 m/s at 7 s, which, simultaneously, causes the mechanical torque disturbance. This process can be regarded as wind speed fluctuation between the measurement gaps. Figure 5 shows the comparison of the disturbance rejection performance toward the mechanical torque disturbance. Figure 5(a) shows the comparison of the rotational velocity, Figure 5(b) shows the estimated mechanical torque, and Figure 5(c) shows the estimated uncertain term
δ
3
. As Figure 5 reveals, when the wind speed varies during the measurement gap, the torque observer can estimate the variation of mechanical torque and impact
f ( x )
of equation (16) immediately. Meanwhile, the quantity of inaccuracy is also estimated and compensated into the control signal.

caption.p: The robustness to mechanical torque disturbance.
PI: proportional–integral control

sec.title: Robustness to stator parameter uncertainties
sec.p:
Generally speaking, the uncertainties of PMSG are caused by two factors, that is, the environmental influence (for SPMSG and IPMSG) and the motor saliency (for IPMSG). For the SPMSG, supposing due to the environment influence, the motor starts with the stator resistance uncertainty of 0.003
Ω
and stator inductance uncertainty of −1 mH. In addition, to study the motor saliency in IPMSG, two sinusoidal signals with the same frequency of 72 Hz, same amplitude of 0.1 mH, and the same phase differential of 90° are added to the inductances, respectively.

Figure 6 shows the rotational velocity response curves. As Figure 6 reveals, under the PI control, an overshot of 3.57% is observed due to the uncertainty in the stator resistance. In contrast, the proposed scheme guarantees 1.14% overshot.

caption.p: Rotational velocity response curves at starting with Rs = 0.009 Ω.
PI: proportional–integral control

sec.p: Figures 7–9 show results in the SPMSG and IPMSG, respectively. In Figure 7, γ-axis current components (Figure 7(a)) and phase-a current (Figure 7(b)) under PI-decoupling methods have deviated from the results under proposed method. In Figure 9, the responses deviated from those in Figure 8 with much periodic ripples. This can be explained as follows.

caption.p: Control performance at starting with Ls =1.5 mH for SPMSG (a) γ-axis current component and (b) phase-a current.
SPMSG: surface permanent magnetic synchronous generator;
PI: proportional–integral control.
Control performance with proposed controller at starting with Ls =1.5 mH for IPMSG (a) γ-axis current component and (b) phase-a current.
IPMSG: interior permanent magnetic synchronous generator.
Control performance with conventional PI decoupling controller at starting with Ls =1.5 mH for IPMSG (a) γ-axis current component and (b) phase-a current.
IPMSG: interior permanent magnetic synchronous generator; PI: proportional–integral control.

sec.p: Due to the parameter uncertainties, the equivalent feedback gain of the closed-loop controller is increased, which reduces the stability margins. The large overshoot and damped oscillations at the step change in the rotational velocity, and stator current are indeed the natural result of the poor relative stability of the control system under uncertainties. Additionally, due to the motor saliency, the equivalent feedback gain of the closed-loop controller is changed periodically, which, consequently, causes much periodic ripples in armature currents. Moreover, the environment causing uncertainties in stator inductions increase the bandwidth of the closed-loop controller. The high bandwidth will make the closed-loop system too sensitive to high frequency noises.

The environment-causing variation of inductances is identified by identified parameters, and they are directly used to adjust the model parameters of controller, whereas the motor saliency effect causing periodic uncertainties are estimated by the DO in adaptive controller. Moreover, the DO estimates these differences between actual model and estimated model, which, in turn, are compensated in the adaptive controller. Since the parameters of controller are adjusted by these identified parameters, and the DO merely estimates the model differences, the pressure of estimation has been greatly reduced. As a result, the robustness of the controller is significantly improved.

sec.title: Power extracting performance
sec.p: Figure 10 shows the wind profile of one-dimensional wind field produced by GH Bladed 3.72 with the mean speed of 12 m/s, the direction perpendicular to the wind turbine sweep plane, turbulence intensity of 16%, and a sampling rate of 30/min. Figures 11–14 are the simulation results for direct-driven IPMSG (DD-IPMSG). Figure 11 shows the results of the actual and estimated rotational velocity, while Figure 12 shows the power coefficient and blade–tip ratio. In Figure 11(b), except for the first 3000 points in transient process, the mean value (−0.03) and maximum velocity error (−12.3676) of the proposed method are superior to mean value (−0.1125) and maximum velocity error (−26.7664) of the PI decoupling controller. In Figure 12(a), blade–tip ratio of proposed method is more close to the optimal value 6.4 compared to the PI-decoupling control; accordingly, in Figure 12(b), the mean (0.4371) and minimum (0.4286) values of power coefficient of the proposed method are superior to the mean (0.4206) and minimum (0.4037) values of the power coefficient of the PI decoupling controller.

caption.p: Wind profile.
Rotational velocity and errors starting with Rs = 0.009 Ω and Ls = 1.5 mH for DD-IPMSG (a) rotational velocity and (b) speed errors.
DD-IPMSG: direct-driven interior permanent magnetic synchronous generator; PI: proportional–integral control.
Power coefficient and blade–tip ratio starting with Rs = 0.009 Ω and Ls = 1.5 mH for DD-IPMSG (a) tip–speed ratio and (b) power coefficient.
DD-IPMSG: direct-driven interior permanent magnetic synchronous generator; PI: proportional–integral control.
Control performance with proposed controller starting with Rs = 0.009 Ω and Ls = 1.5 mH for DD-IPMSG (a) γ-axis current component and (b) phase-a current.
DD-IPMSG: direct-driven interior permanent magnetic synchronous generator.
Control performance with PI decoupling controller starting with Rs = 0.009 Ω and Ls = 1.5 mH for DD-IPMSG (a) γ-axis current component and (b) phase-a current.
DD-IPMSG: direct-driven interior permanent magnetic synchronous generator; PI: proportional–integral control.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article presents a new approach of designing robust controller for a DD-PMSG WECS without mechanical sensors based on MRABC. By utilizing the identified stator parameters and the estimated mechanical torque, the adaptive mechanism only estimates the uncertain terms of d-axis, q-axis, and the velocity loop, which can alleviate estimation pressure of adaptive mechanism and greatly improve the estimation accuracy. As a result, the robustness against parameter uncertainties and mechanical torque ripples is improved. Meanwhile, based on the Lyapunov stable theory, a theoretical demonstration for the feasibility of substituting the actual stator parameters and state vector with the identified and estimated values during the EEMF estimation is given. Finally, comparative evaluations have been carried out to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme under different operating conditions.
